frontmatter.title: Appendix 2: The Principle of Least Squares

children.value: When we make multiple measurements of a quantity that contains random fluctuation, we need a method to determine the most probable value. The principle of least squares provides this method by finding the value that minimizes the squared deviations from our measurements.

children.value: Weighted least squares is particularly valuable when measurements come from different sources with varying precision. By accounting for these differences in precision, we ensure that our fitted parameters are not unduly influenced by less reliable data points.

When reporting results from weighted analyses, it’s important to specify that weighted methods were used and to explain the basis for the weights assigned. This transparency allows others to properly interpret and potentially reproduce your analysis.
